For the third year in a row, I visited the leadership of the Shinnecock Indian Nation on their land. The Shinnecocks are a proud and resilient people whose sovereignty is guaranteed under federal law.

We spoke about their commitment to self-sufficiency and their federally protected right to use their land—rights I strongly support. When controversy arose years ago over their plan to build a digital advertising sign along Sunrise Highway, the Shinnecock leaders worked with state and local officials to ensure all requirements were met. Yet objections persisted until the courts rightly affirmed that most state and local zoning rules do not apply to federally recognized tribal land.

Too often, some state and local officials claim to “protect Native American culture” by banning the use of Native names as mascots. If they truly want to respect Native culture, they should instead stop interfering with tribes’ reasonable and federally guaranteed use of their own land.
